Now, the problem is how do you still get a feeling of the social learning and that sort of thing if everybody has headphones and are staring at their computer? So, we try to alternate. Like when we do the in-person workshops, we try to alternate between your self-paced learning time and then pairing time. So, you might learn at your own pace for two hours and then weâ€™re going to put you in a pair and youâ€™re going to work on whatever project is at the level that youâ€™re at right now. And youâ€™ll do that for 45 minutes. And thatâ€™s a chance to just explore something more and do something a little more freeform. And then you go back to this more structured learning. And thatâ€™s the format that weâ€™ve come up with, because then you get to have the best of both worlds. Because of what Iâ€™ve seen is when people do teach themselves, if you teach in a traditional way itâ€™s easy to leave people behind. Itâ€™s easy to not go at the right pace. Itâ€™s also easy to mess up. Sometimes, Iâ€™ve taught the same things many times. Sometimes I teach it well. Sometimes I teach it shit because I just mess some critical thing up. And so, if I put it online then I just have to improve that online thing and I donâ€™t have to worry about messing it up next time I teach it. So, I think that itâ€™s a good thing for those bootcamps and schools to use self-paced curriculum thatâ€™s online and then figure out how they can add more group and pairing stuff to that curriculum.
